 The Complete Guide to



 Overview

Camping is an outdoor recreational activity involving overnight stays away from home in a shelter such as a tent, a caravan, or a motorhome. Generally participants leave developed areas to spend time outdoors in more natural ones in pursuit of activities providing them enjoyment. To be regarded as "camping" a minimum of one night is spent outdoors, distinguishing it from day-tripping, picnicking, and other similarly short-term recreational activities.

  All The Thing That Are Not Mentioned In Including Section

 Things To Pack

   Shoes: You need good trekking shoes with good grip.

  Clothing: You need to have warm clothes with three-layer jackets, fleece or down feather jacket. Carry 1 or 2 full sleeves t-shirt. For lowers carry cotton pants suitable for trek. Do no carry jeans or shorts for trekking.

  Thermals: Carry top and bottom thermals.

  Socks: Carry 2 - 3 pair of sports socks along with woolen socks to be worn at night.

  Headlamp/Led Torch are mandatory.

  Sunglasses: To protect from sunlight in snow you require UV rays protected sunglasses.

  Woolen Cap and Gloves are also necessary as the climate will be cold. Carry waterproof gloves as they get wet in snow.

  Lunchbox & Water bottle: Every participant should carry lunch box and water bottle of their own.

  Sunscreen, Toiletries and personal items.

  Raincoat/Ponchos: At high altitudes, snowfall and rain are quite common and it’s mandatory to carry a poncho so that one doesn’t get wet.

 Things To Pack

 Frequently Asked Questions

Our rock climbing trips are designed for climbers of all experience levels. Whether you're a beginner or an experienced climber, our guides will work with you to ensure a safe and enjoyable experience.

We provide all necessary climbing equipment, including harnesses, ropes, carabiners, and climbing shoes. You're welcome to bring your own equipment if you prefer.

A typical climbing day begins early in the morning with a hearty breakfast. We'll then head to the climbing location, where our guides will provide instruction and guidance throughout the day. We'll take breaks for lunch and snacks, and return to camp in the evening for dinner and relaxation.

Don't worry! Our guides are trained to work with climbers of all comfort levels. We'll work with you to build your confidence and provide support throughout the trip.

Safety is our top priority. Our guides are certified in wilderness first aid and CPR, and we carry a first aid kit with us at all times. We'll also provide instruction on climbing safety and best practices.

NOTE


  • Safety first: Always wear appropriate safety gear, including a helmet, gloves, and protective clothing.
  • Nagarjun Rock Climbing of Nepal is a living thing, being influenced by multiple factors such as changing weather conditions, group riding abilities, trail damage, to name a few. Your local guides are experts in guiding mountain rockrs in the Himalayas of Nepal and will be continually assessing these factors and making tweaks to the itinerary where necessary to ensure that every member of the group has the best possible experience.
  • Know your limits: Be honest with yourself about your abilities and choose trails that match your skill level. Pushing yourself too hard can lead to accidents or injuries.
  • Be prepared: Carry enough water, snacks, and other essentials like a first aid kit and a rock repair kit. It's better to be over-prepared than under-prepared.
  • Respect nature: Stay on designated trails to avoid damaging the environment. Don't litter or disturb wildlife.
  • Have fun: Remember to enjoy the ride and take in the beautiful scenery around you.
